Spain's People And Tourism

Spain has a deep culture and it is very diverse. A lot of people come to Spain every year and makes the place, an array of cultures and backgrounds. It has a wide history where in the past a lot of other countries and people invaded Spain and tried to take control of the land. The people include the Romans. This led to the mixture of cultures and a deep rooted history.Spain is also home to some very famous artists like Picasso and architects. This makes Spain rich in artistic works. Monuments are all over the place and so are great architectural works and art works of the famous artists of days gone.The Spaniards are indeed very friendly and charming. They are very warm and inviting and their lifestyles laid back. The weather in Spain is just lovely making it a perfect destination especially for summer holidays. The cuisine is wonderful and the festivals will be unforgettable if you get a chance to witness some. The folklore is most interesting.Geographically speaking, Spain is also very beautiful. It is highly mountainous making it perfect for mountain holidays. During winter, tourists can go ice skiing on the mountains as well as enjoy the most amazing sceneries. Canary Island is home to the highest mountain peak in the world.The beaches are just amazing and you will have a great time relaxing and enjoy the sun. Spain's Religion Involvement In Tourism

To most people, religion and tourism would never mingle. Not so in Spain where religion is a major part of tourism that attracts many visitors every year. There are a lot of factors that have led to religion playing such a major role in the tourism industry in Spain.There are three major religions in Spain namely Judaism, Islam and Catholicism. There are places that can be termed as being the Catholics holiest places in Spain. These include Santiago de Compostela which is in Galicia. This place has been rated as the 3rd holiest place in the world after Vatican City and Jerusalem. It is also home to the Way of Saint James. Also located in north Spain is Cantabria and Santo Toribio de Liébana. The region of Murcia is the 5th holiest city and is located in the South eastern side. All these places are a major tourist attraction.The places receive thousands of tourists and pilgrims each year. They come from all corners of the world. There are also a lot of artistic expressions here. Most of the tourists and pilgrims come here for the processions of the Holy Week. These processions are very popular and are important to many of the towns in Spain.The holy weeks involves a lot of traditions also called Semana Santa. The holy week is Lent’s last week, important to many Christians especially Catholics. Lent is the week just before Easter and there are a lot of glamorous celebrations in many regions.The area recognized for these kind of celebrations is Andalusia, most especially Málaga and Seville. This area receives a lot of visitors during this season. Castile regions are a bit somber and hold solemn events. There is a religious ceremony called Semana Santa which typifies the events.During the processions, many pilgrims wear penitential or nazareno robes which are a common feature. The garment has a hood that has a conical hood that conceals faces. These robes are historic as they were used for penitents in the medieval period so as to demonstrate penance. Other people in the procession wear whatever they like with some using uniforms related to Roman Legion. Cartagena has more unique procession following strict order.Brotherhoods are divided into groups called agrupaciones and are in charge of the floats. Members in a group wear same colours. At the front of each float, there is a standard that is richly embroidered. Top 3 Castles and Palaces of Spain

Palaces and castles are numerous in Spain and they form part of the major monuments and ancient buildings worth visiting while in the country. They not only showcase some of Spain’s epochs but also the great works of architecture of those eras and some of the most famed artists. Here are the top palaces and castles which cannot be missed while in Spain.San Lorenzo de El Escorial: it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site thanks to its unique and beautiful decorations. This is one of Spain’s most popular attractions and is in Madrid. It was a royal residence which still attracts thousands of tourists because of its magnificence. Some of the features that make the palace most outstanding include the interior decoration that is rich and done by some of Spain’s greatest artists. They include El Greco. Tiziano, Vecellie as well as Diego Rodriguez de Silva. It is also home to rare paintings which are well preserved and the ceiling is adorned by hundreds of frescos. It is simply a place you cannot miss in Spain.Castillo de la Mota: the castle is a medieval fortress that is quite beautiful. It got the name La Mota from the mountain that it sits on and you will find it in the Valladolid province in Spain. It is mainly made of two parts with one being the massive towers of stone forming the citadel and the Santa Maria Mayor Abbey. You will find in the castle El Greco’s paintings, a mosque, and a Gothic church. The town can be viewed from one of the towers from where the beauty of the neighborhood id enjoyed. The town walls are also visible from here.Castillo de Coca: it is among Spain’s most beautiful fortresses of the medieval times. It is a treasure well preserved as far as the Spanish medieval architecture is concerned and sits above Voltoya River in Coca Town. This castle has a deep and broad moat serving as its protection and also to behold is the magnificent interior decoration. Some of the features within it include geometric motifs and vault mosaics which are Gothic. Amazing Attractions at Cordoba

One of Andalusia’s finest cities to visit is Córdoba which offers lots of breath-taking attractions from the past and nature.Historical cityCórdoba was a Romans set up city to be used as a navigational point as it lies on River Rio Guadalquivar. This makes Córdoba very strategic in boosting its port activities as the Romans identified the great potential in this city. In its early days, Córdoba enjoyed a high volume of shipping activity involving regional commerce trading Spanish produce such as olive oil, wine and wheat.An impressive Roman bridge named “El Puente Romano” plies over River Rio Guadalquivar that symbolizes the Romans’ presence and the city’s grandeur in those days.The Arabs took over Córdoba between 711 AD and 1263 AD with the exquisite Mezquita mosque built in 784 AD. The mosque became world renowned as the world’s largest mosque during the 10th century. The city fell to the Christian Re-conquest hands in the year 1236 who added on splendid architectural designs to match the Mezquita’s beauty before turning it into a majestic Cathedral.The Jews left their influence at Córdoba at its ancient quarters through its elaborate labyrinth of winding narrow cobbled streets. There are picturesque squares with beautiful shady patios and courtyards which were lined with a variety of flowers.Town attractionsThere is an annual competition for the most beautiful courtyard in May that is undertaken by the locals. This is part of the tradition of decorating patios and courtyards with fresh flowers especially those in bloom. The public gets to feast on these delightfully decorated patios and courtyards before voting for the best.Visitors would enjoy the numerous natural landscapes around Córdoba; one of them is the Alcazar Reyes gardens which used to be an ancient palace. The local museum of Vivo de Al-Andalus showcases a plethora of interesting Roman artifacts and architectural delights. The museum is excellent in helping visitors to Córdoba understand its history and beauty.One would enjoy the great view at the top of the Vivo de Al-Andalus museum with a challenge on the climb to the tower. Besides the majestic view of Cordoba, one can enjoy two ancient Arabic water mills although only one is functional with a restored waterwheel.The Vivo museum is an archeological museum that houses interesting historical artifacts around the Spanish region with lots of fantastic stories. The Delightful Charms of Antequera

An Andalucia visit should include quaint Antequera which is in the province of Malaga. It is an exciting town which is full of history and culture that goes back 5,000 years covering the Bronze Age. The Iberian natives can be identified from the mystical burial mounds and tombs to offer a clearer historical timeline.Further evidences stem from the presence of ancient remnants such as churches and cathedrals; Roman baths and Moorish castles as well as Renaissance fountains and Baroque bell towers shape the culture and traditions of the region.Surrounding charmsAntequera is surrounded by lots of natural beauty with a typical medieval ambience as whitewashed houses line the streets with historical buildings neatly tucked away for the curious and the adventurous.There are plenty of historical gems which can be discovered in Antequera; the El Torcal is considered a natural wonder in this part of the world in its lofty position on the mountain range to protect Antequera over the decades.Vast plains form fertile and productive farmlands across La Vega with a constant supply from Guadalhorce River to produce the best of fruits and vegetables from this region.An 800-meter limestone cliff called the Lovers’ Leap stands high to remind all and sundry of the tragic love story of a Christian boy falling for a Moorish girl who reciprocated his love. A statue of commemoration stands in the town plaza as a constant reminder.The rock head Peña landscape that forms the image of an Indian hero stands out for miles like a guardian angel over the farmlands and fruit orchards while adding mystic and grandeur to the surroundings. The people are known to be very warm and friendly while the weather is also warm for a great part of the year. Other things that attract people to Spain include folklore, famous festivities, the nightlife, cuisine, the lifestyle among many others. It is a very diverse land where everyone will find something to their fancy. Diversity in this case covers both the cultural as well as the geographical aspect. An Impactful Holiday with El Escorial

El Escorial is an interesting small town which has varied historical attractions; one of them is the biggest monastery found in Spain. This large rectangular building was built during the Renaissance but its exterior poses like a harsh prison rather than a palace.

This special monument was built between 1563 and 1584 by Juan Bautista Toledo. Felipe II planned it as a mausoleum cum monastery when he expressed a desire to spend his life like a monk.

Later monarchs transformed the drab-looking monument interiors with rich décor in keeping with their affluent lifestyles. However, Felipe’s personal rooms were left untouched as when he passed away. His favorite bed and support chair remained in his room where he used to look out to the courtyard and quaint chapel where Masses were held.

Gastronomy

Besides local historical attractions, El Escorial has many interesting nooks and corners for scrumptious local delicacies. There are plenty of good restaurants serving delightful local cuisines besides the fancy and upper class restaurants found in hotels.

There are many types of sumptuous food at El Escorial. One of the more delightful local dishes is the stews which are made of traditional secret recipes. The fish is another popular choice among the locals at El Escorial. These tantalizing local dishes usually go well with the fine local wines available from the region’s best vineyards. Bocadillo is another preferred choice to go with the local cuisine.

Tourists are delighted at these treats as they are not only easily available but also affordable. With the plethora of pubs and bars in El Escorial, the locals and tourists have no problem enjoying the town and its region anytime for food or drinks.

Great holiday option

El Escorial may not be considered a city but it still offers several cinemas to entertain the locals and tourists in town. Numerous theatrical mementoes are performed depending on the demand of the crowd; jazz and classical concerts are frequently performed at the local Coliseo which dates back to 18th century.

Numerous theatrical productions are available throughout the year with a free weekly performance.

El Escorial is a great holiday vacation choice from the myriad of holiday packages available. The itinerary includes visiting the historical basilica, famous monastery, royal apartments, chapter houses, sacristy and public library. There are also castles and natural landscapes which would delight the tourists.

Great holiday package deals on Es Escorial can be secured in advance or upon arrival to the town. Guided tours in coaches offer a great way to view the town and its sights in comfort.

Naturally Beautiful Salobreña At Granada

The town of Salobrena is only 2 kilometers from the lovely beach and warm sea waters. There is little development happening at and around Salobrena which maintains the beach’s beauty. The natural beauty of the town’s surroundings spans far and wide to please the eye.

One of the uniqueness at Salobrena is its black sandy beach. It is soft and clean that makes it enjoyable for all.

Accessibility

Salobrena is growing popular as a holiday resort for its quaint black sandy beaches and unadulterated surroundings. Its easy accessibility from around Spain through its efficient local public buses makes Salobrena a preferred choice for many tourists.

The frequent buses plying the town bring in flocks of tourists even for a weekend escapade. These stop at Plaza de Goya with a nearby turismo or tourist center which allows tourists to secure the necessary information on their holiday weekend such as place of stay and gastronomy delights.

Accommodation

The accommodation at Salobrena is clean and comfortable with basic amenities that would give tourists a good night’s rest. The cheap accommodation attracts more tourists to Salobrena especially in the summer. Advanced booking is usually required as more tourists are choosing Salobrena for their summer vacation.

The more adventurous can also try camping at El Sotillo campsite located near the town. Camping is also a cheaper form of accommodation with more freedom of movement while offering more adventure.

Vibrant hospitality

There are plenty of pubs, bars, restaurants and cafés at Salobrena that serve delightful local cuisine. Chiringuitos can be found along the seafront to enjoy fresh and tasty seafood at low prices.

Tapas and paella go well with a pint of cold beer while lazing around the beach or pub in the cool evening. The atmosphere is vibrant with music and social interactions where the locals extend their hospitality. No one would go hungry with the myriad of delectable cuisine available.
